The Quantification and Analysis of Information Used in Decision Processes*
BRUCE J. WHITTEMORE** and M. C. YOVITS1'
Department of Computer and Information Science, The Ohio State University, Columbus, Ohio
Communicated by J. M. Richardson
ABSTRACT
If information science is to be considered a "science" in the true sense of the word, there is a clear need for the development of a set of general concepts and analytical expressions regarding the flow of information in any situation for which information serves as a re- source. This paper discusses quantitative aspects of a theory leading to the development of such a pragmatic information theory. At the heart of a theory of pragmatic information is the measure of information contained in a set of data. At the pragmatic level, information has value to the extent that it is useful as a resource for purposeful activity. The primary "purposeful activity" in life is decision-making. Hence, information and decision-making are inextricably tied together; in fact, information is data of value in decision-making. In this paper, we discuss quantitatively a very general decision model which provides a formal and comprehensive representation of uncertainty in decision-making. Other decision models presented in the literature assume away a considerable and important portion of the uncer- tainty that exists in decision-making. This model is then used as a framework for examining the role of information in decision-making in a way that is also formal and comprehensive. Hence, the decision model suggested facilitates a meaningful analysis of information; this analysis culminates in the development of a measure of the value of the pragmatic informa- tion contained in a set of data.
1. INTRODUCTION
This paper discusses certain quantitative aspects of previously published ma- terial [1-3] by the authors and others. The overall objective of this research is to establish a fundamental theory for the analysis and flow of information. Such

a theory would include fundamental relationships, measures, and quantitative expressions about information flow in any situation for which information serves as a resource. In this theoretical development we relate information to decision- making. Accordingly, one of the objectives of this approach is to establish prin- ciples and guidelines regarding the use of information in decision processes.
Weaver [4] has suggested a three-fold classification of the communications problems of interest in information science: (1) the technical problem; (2) the semantic problem; and (3) the effectiveness (or behavioral) problem. Problems at the first level are well in hand. The significance of Shannon's work [4] on communication theory is, of course, widely recognized. The treatment of prob- lems at the second level has been somewhat less complete than the treatment of those at the first level; nevertheless, significant and quite widely accepted work of a fundamental nature (e.g., by such people as Carnap and Bar-Hillel [5], Winograd [6], and others) does exist. However, no comprehensive and widely accepted theory of information at the third level has yet been published, despite its clear significance.
The effectiveness or behavioral problem involves an investigation of the use and effect of information on human activity. Studies in this area involve the re- lationship between information, communication processes, and human behav- ioral activities. A comprehensive theory dealing with communications problems at this third level would consist, in part, of situation-dependent and time- dependent measures of the effect of information on any activity for which infor- mation serves as a resource. Furthermore, it would contain fundamental expres- sions regarding the flow of information in any such situation. Using the termi- nology of the linguist, we may refer to such a theory as a theory of pragmatic information.
In this paper, we discuss quantitatively a generalized decision model which provides a formal and comprehensive representation of uncertainty in decision- making. This model is then used as a framework for examining the role of infor- mation in decision-making in a way that is also formal and comprehensive. Hence, the generalized decision model facilitates a meaningful analysis of infor- mation, culminating in the development of a measure of the value of the prag- matic information contained in a set of data.
2.BACKGROUND
At the pragmatic level, the primary activity for which information serves as a resource is decision-making. Information is used for making decisions; it is ac- quired, processed, and disseminated for this very reason. Hence, information and decision-making are inextricably tied together. Indeed, information can be defined as data of value in decision-making. In [1 ] and [2], one of the authors has discussed the basis for such a definition as well as the implications thereof.

In particular, this definition gives rise to the generalized information system model depicted in Fig. 1. This model is a perfectly general one, limited only by three basic hypotheses.
The first hypothesis is that there is a close interrelationship between informa- tion and decision-making; this interrelationship gives rise to the definition of in- formation stated. The second hypothesis is related to the ability to measure or quantify information or even to know of its existence. In the physical world, the only way in which a real parameter, say a mass or a force, can be measured, is by its interaction with the environment. If this interaction does not exist, then it is impossible, almost by definition, to measure a quantity or even to es- tablish its existence. One ought to be able to make the same statement about in- formation. It is necessary that the information produce physical interaction- with the real world. In any real situation it must give rise to an observable effect. The third hypothesis which the model is to satisfy is the necessity that the decision-maker must have some way of comparing predicted observables with the actual observables that result from any decision for which he is responsible. The decision-maker generates a course of action which he believes will have cer- tain observable effects. It is only after comparing the actual observables with those he has predicted, that he has some way of verifying the validity of his course of action. In other words, the third hypothesis dictates that the general- ized model must have feedback between the resulting observables and the decision-maker.
In a recent paper [3], the authors provide further refinement and extension for some of the relationships suggested in [1] and [2]. In [3], a new and quite general decision model was developed; such a decision model was necessary pri- marily because existing decision models do not provide a comprehensive rep- resentation of uncertainty. Specifically, the group to whom typical decision models (as found in voluminous form in the decision theoretic literature) are addressed consists of decision-makers who are assumed to have reached a rather

advanced state of knowledge about the decision situation in questioni.e., decision-makers who have already resolved a considerable amount of uncertainty. This shortcoming is important because a formal and comprehensive analysis of the role of information in decision-making can only be founded on a decision model that provides a formal and comprehensive representation of uncertainty in decision-making.
In other words, the decision theoretic literature which exists in voluminous form treats the situation where the decision-maker already has a high degree of expertise. On the other hand, the information science aspects of decision theory must cover comprehensively those decision-makers who not only are expert, but those decision-makers who may be mediocre or even rather poor. A large part of the development of information systems is clearly aimed at the non-expert or even the novice decision-maker. It is, therefore, most important in developing a formal role for information science that all levels of effectiveness of decision- makers be considered.
In [3] we point out that a decision-maker (DM) must contend (either con- sciously or unconsciously) with two fundamental types of uncertainty: struc- tural uncertainty and relational uncertainty. The DM must first attempt to identify the basic structure of the situation: the nature and number of elements involved. Given some representation of this basic structure (albeit incomplete or even totally incorrect), the DM can then attempt to assess the nature of the relationships between these elements.
At the same time another categorization of uncertainty exists. It is seen from Fig. 1 that the execution of courses of action results in observable outcomes; yet there is executional uncertainty associated with predicting exactly which out- come will occur when a given action is executed. Furthermore, deciding which course of action to select involves consideration of the relative desirability of possible decision outcomes; this "relative desirability" can be determined only by addressing goal uncertainty. Finally, the state of the external environment

The generalized decision model discussed above provides a framework for ex- amining the role of information in decision-making in a way that is formal, com- prehensive, and meaningful. Let us begin this examination and analysis by con- sidering the separate effects of information on the various types of uncertainty;
we will then consider the aggregated effect.
The information contained in a set of data (either unexpected new data from the external environment or feedback data from past decisions) has either struc- tural value or relational value or both. If the data indicate to the DM that his understanding of the structural components of the decision situation is incom- plete and/or incorrect, then these data contain structural information. On the other hand, data that help the DM refine his model of the relationships that exist between known structural components contain relational information. These concepts are elaborated on at length in [3].
Consider the DM who has resolved a certain amount of structural uncertainty;
i.e., he has a rather good idea as to his decision goals, the available courses of action, the possible decision outcomes, and the relevant states of nature. The DM's current lists of mutually exclusive courses of action, decision outcomes, and states of nature can be made exhaustive by the addition of a "catch-all category" in each case. For example, if the DM can identify n - 1 possible de- cision outcomes, then o represents "the occurrence of some other, unexpected outcome." Similarly, alternative dm denotes "any other course of action" and state Sr denotes "any other relevant state of nature." Here the role of relational information (either new information from the external environment or feedback information) can be discussed in rather precise quantitative terms.

It is important to recognize that the learning rules discussed above are only suggestive and/or illustrative of what a reasonable DM might, or in some cases, should do. The way in which a particular DM actually uses information to revise or reinforce his current understanding of the decision situation is, of course, a highly individualistic process. Hence, the learning rules suggested here are only meant to be examples of ways in which a DM's representation of uncertainty might be revised or reinforced. The fact that the decision model suggested here is amenable to the application of these and other learning rules is clearly an indi- cation of its generality.
Although the separate effects of the various types of information are clearly important, they are really only of major significance in their combined effect on the DM's understanding of the situation. The amount or value of the informa- tion contained in a set of data cannot be meaningfully expressed except in terms of how these data affect the DM's model of the decision situation. One of the purposes of this study is to suggest a measure of pragmatic information that sub- sumes any possible measure of amount of information in that it is, in fact, a mea- sure of the value of an amount of information.
Information has value in decision-making to the extent that it changes the DM's state of knowledge about a decision situation or, to use MacKay's [13] terminology, his "state of conditional readiness" for making that decision. The generalized decision model provides the means by which this notion of a deci- sion state can be readily represented.
Regardless of what decision rule a DM is utilizing, it is possible to obtain a dis- tribution that reflects his overall inclination toward the various courses of action. For example, as we have already considered, if the DM is an expected value maximizer, he will select course of action a* according to Eqs. (3.1) and (3.2).

4. CONCLUSION
In information science there is a need for the development of a theory of pragmatic information. Such a theory would relate information to its use and usefulness in choice situations; it would treat information as a resource whose value is relative. At the heart of such a theory would be a measure of the prag- matic information content of a message for a particular decision-maker in a par- ticular decision situation at a particular point in time.
The measure defined in equation (3.16) is suggested as such a measure and is, therefore, thought to be of major importance. Some additional implications of this measure are suggested in [3]. In general, this measure quantifies informa- tion in terms of its effect on the state of the decision-maker. A decision state is defined so that it represents a complete quantitative description of the DM's cur- rent understanding of a decision situation. The detailed development of this measure is the primary contribution of this study to information science.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: If information science is to be considered a “science” in the true sense of the word, there is a clear need for the development of a set of general concepts and analytical expressions regarding the flow of information in any situation for which information serves as a resource. This paper discusses quantitative aspects of a theory leading to the development of such a pragmatic information theory. At the heart of a theory of pragmatic information is the measure of information contained in a set of data. At the pragmatic level, information has value to the extent that it is useful as a resource for purposeful activity. The primary “purposeful activity” in life is decision-making. Hence, information and decision-making are inextricably tied together; in fact, information is data of value in decision-making. In this paper, we discuss quantitatively a very general decision model which provides a formal and comprehensive representation of uncertainty in decision-making. Other decision models presented in the literature assume away a considerable and important portion of the uncertainty that exists in decision-making. This model is then used as a framework for examining the role of information in decision-making in a way that is also formal and comprehensive. Hence, the decision model suggested facilitates a meaningful analysis of information; this analysis culminates in the development of a measure of the value of the pragmatic information contained in a set of data.
